natural solution: More generally, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & a \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & a + b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]Therefore, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 + 3 + 5 + \dots + 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}.\]

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real mat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. f n = mat_of_rows_list 2 [[1, real (2*n+1)], [0, 1]]"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. f (n+1) = f n * f 1"

a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find
\[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 More generally, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & a \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & a + b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]Therefore, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 + 3 + 5 + \dots + 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}.\]

fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real mat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. f n = mat_of_rows_list 2 [[1, real (2*n+1)], [0, 1]]"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. f (n+1) = f n * f 1"
shows  "f 50 = mat_of_rows_list 2 [[1, 2500], [0, 1]]"

a_1.informal problem: A sequence of 2x2 matrices $f(n)$ is defined for natural numbers $n$ where each matrix $f(n)$ has elements defined as follows: the first row is [1, 2n+1] and the second row is [0, 1]. Additionally, for every $n$, the (n+1)th matrix is the product of the nth matrix and the first matrix. What is the 50th matrix in this sequence? The final Answer is [[1, 2500], [0, 1]].

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. A n = (\<chi> i j. if (i = 1 \<and> j = 1) then 1 else if (i = 2 \<and> j = 2) then 1 else if (i = 1 \<and> j = 2) then real (2*n + 1) else 0)"
shows  "(\<Prod>n\<le>49. A n) = (\<chi> i j. if (i = 1 \<and> j = 1) then 1 else if (i = 2 \<and> j = 2) then 1 else if (i = 1 \<and> j = 2) then 2500 else 0)"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find
\[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 More generally, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & a \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & a + b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]Therefore, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 + 3 + 5 + \dots + 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. A n = (\<chi> i j. if (i = 1 \<and> j = 1) then 1 else if (i = 2 \<and> j = 2) then 1 else if (i = 1 \<and> j = 2) then real (2*n + 1) else 0)"
shows  "(\<Prod>n\<le>49. A n) = (\<chi> i j. if (i = 1 \<and> j = 1) then 1 else if (i = 2 \<and> j = 2) then 1 else if (i = 1 \<and> j = 2) then 2500 else 0)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: For each natural number $n$, a 2x2 matrix $A$ is defined where $A_{11} = A_{22} = 1$, $A_{12} = 2n + 1$, and $A_{21} = 0$. What is the product of these matrices for all $n$ up to 49? The final answer is a matrix where $A_{11} = A_{22} = 1$, $A_{12} = 2500$, and $A_{21} = 0$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes M :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real^2^2" and P :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. M n = matrix([[1, real (2*n)], [0, 1]])"
and h1 : "P = foldl1 (\<circ>) (map M [1..50])"
shows  "P = matrix([[1, 2500], [0, 1]])"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find
\[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 More generally, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & a \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & a + b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]Therefore, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 + 3 + 5 + \dots + 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes M :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real^2^2" and P :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. M n = matrix([[1, real (2*n)], [0, 1]])"
and h1 : "P = foldl1 (\<circ>) (map M [1..50])"
shows  "P = matrix([[1, 2500], [0, 1]])"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Consider a sequence of 2x2 matrices $M(n)$ where each matrix is defined as $M(n) = \begin{{bmatrix}} 1 & 2n \\ 0 & 1 \end{{bmatrix}}$ for all natural numbers $n$. Now, let $P$ be the result of applying function composition to the matrices $M(1), M(2), ..., M(50)$ in this order. What is the matrix $P$? The final answer is $\begin{{bmatrix}} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{{bmatrix}}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. A n = matrix([[1, real(n)],[0,1]])"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 50 \<longrightarrow> A n ** A (2*n) = matrix([[1, 100 * real(n)],[0,1]])"
shows  "A 50 ** A 100 = matrix([[1, 2500],[0,1]])"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find
\[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 More generally, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & a \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & a + b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]Therefore, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 + 3 + 5 + \dots + 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. A n = matrix([[1, real(n)],[0,1]])"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 50 \<longrightarrow> A n ** A (2*n) = matrix([[1, 100 * real(n)],[0,1]])"
shows  "A 50 ** A 100 = matrix([[1, 2500],[0,1]])"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Consider a matrix $A$ with natural number entries defined by $A(n) = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & n \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$. For all $n$ from $1$ to $50$, the product of $A(n)$ and $A(2n)$ is the matrix $\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 100n \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$. What is the product of $A(50)$ and $A(100)$? The final answer is $\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes M :: "nat \<Rightarrow> (nat, nat) mat"
assumes h0 : "M 1 = mat 2 2 (\<lambda>(i,j). if i = j then 1 else if i < j then 1 else 0)"
and h1 : "\<forall>n\<ge>1. M n = mat 2 2 (\<lambda>(i,j). if i = j then 1 else if i < j then 2*n else 0)"
shows  "mat_multseq M 1 50 = mat 2 2 (\<lambda>(i,j). if i = j then 1 else if i < j then 2500 else 0)"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find
\[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 More generally, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & a \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & a + b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]Therefore, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 + 3 + 5 + \dots + 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes M :: "nat \<Rightarrow> (nat, nat) mat"
assumes h0 : "M 1 = mat 2 2 (\<lambda>(i,j). if i = j then 1 else if i < j then 1 else 0)"
and h1 : "\<forall>n\<ge>1. M n = mat 2 2 (\<lambda>(i,j). if i = j then 1 else if i < j then 2*n else 0)"
shows  "mat_multseq M 1 50 = mat 2 2 (\<lambda>(i,j). if i = j then 1 else if i < j then 2500 else 0)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem:
Given a sequence of 2x2 matrices $M_n$ defined as follows:

- $M_1$ is the 2x2 matrix where the diagonal entries are 1, and the upper triangular entry is 1, and the lower triangular entry is 0.
- For $n \geq 1$, $M_n$ is the 2x2 matrix where the diagonal entries are 1, the upper triangular entry is $2n$, and the lower triangular entry is 0.

What is the product of the first 50 matrices in this sequence? The final answer is the 2x2 matrix where the diagonal entries are 1, the upper triangular entry is 2500, and the lower triangular entry is 0.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. A n = matrix([[1, real n], [0, 1]])"
and h1 : "\<forall> n \<in> {1..99}. A n * A (n + 1) = A (n + 1)"
shows  "A 99 = matrix([[1, 2500], [0, 1]])"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find
\[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 More generally, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & a \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & a + b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]Therefore, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 + 3 + 5 + \dots + 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. A n = matrix([[1, real n], [0, 1]])"
and h1 : "\<forall> n \<in> {1..99}. A n * A (n + 1) = A (n + 1)"
shows  "A 99 = matrix([[1, 2500], [0, 1]])"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Consider a sequence of 2x2 matrices $A_n$ for $n$ in the natural numbers, defined by $A_n = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & n \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$. If for all $n$ from 1 to 99, the product $A_n * A_{n+1}$ equals $A_{n+1}$, find the matrix $A_{99}$. The final answer is $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. A n = matrix([[1, real (n*2+1)], [0, 1]])"
and h1 : "finite {n. n \<le> 49}"
shows  "matrix([[1, 2500], [0, 1]]) = (PROD n:{n. n \<le> 49}. A n)"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find
\[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 More generally, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & a \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & a + b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]Therefore, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 + 3 + 5 + \dots + 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. A n = matrix([[1, real (n*2+1)], [0, 1]])"
and h1 : "finite {n. n \<le> 49}"
shows  "matrix([[1, 2500], [0, 1]]) = (PROD n:{n. n \<le> 49}. A n)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given a sequence of 2x2 matrices $A_n = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2n+1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$ for $n \leq 49$, find the product of these matrices. The final answer is $\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. A n = (\<chi> i j. if j = 1 then (if i = 1 then 1 else 0) else (if i = 1 then 2 * n else 1))"
and h1 : "finite {n. n \<in> {1..50}}"
shows  "(\<Prod>n\<in>{1..50}. A n) = (\<chi> i j. if j = 1 then (if i = 1 then 1 else 0) else (if i = 1 then 2500 else 1))"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find
\[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 More generally, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & a \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & a + b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]Therefore, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 + 3 + 5 + \dots + 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. A n = (\<chi> i j. if j = 1 then (if i = 1 then 1 else 0) else (if i = 1 then 2 * n else 1))"
and h1 : "finite {n. n \<in> {1..50}}"
shows  "(\<Prod>n\<in>{1..50}. A n) = (\<chi> i j. if j = 1 then (if i = 1 then 1 else 0) else (if i = 1 then 2500 else 1))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Consider a function $A: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{2 \times 2}$ defined as follows: for each natural number $n$, $A(n)$ is a $2 \times 2$ matrix where the entry at the first row and first column is $1$, the entry at the first row and second column is $2n$, the entry at the second row and first column is $0$, and the entry at the second row and second column is $1$. Now, consider the product of $A(n)$ for all $n$ from $1$ to $50$. Is it true that this product is a $2 \times 2$ matrix where the entry at the first row and first column is $1$, the entry at the first row and second column is $2500$, the entry at the second row and first column is $0$, and the entry at the second row and second column is $1$?

a_9.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes A :: "int \<Rightarrow> int mat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> k. A k = mat 2 2 (\<lambda>(i, j). if i = j then 1 else if j = 1 then 0 else 2*k)"
and h1 : "mat 2 2 (\<lambda>(i, j). if i = j then 1 else if j = 1 then 0 else 2500) = foldr1 mat_mult (map A [1..50])"
shows  "\<forall> k. A k * A (k+1) = mat 2 2 (\<lambda>(i, j). if i = j then 1 else if j = 1 then 0 else 2*(k+1)^2)"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find
\[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 More generally, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & a \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & a + b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]Therefore, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 + 3 + 5 + \dots + 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem 
fixes A :: "int \<Rightarrow> int mat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> k. A k = mat 2 2 (\<lambda>(i, j). if i = j then 1 else if j = 1 then 0 else 2*k)"
and h1 : "mat 2 2 (\<lambda>(i, j). if i = j then 1 else if j = 1 then 0 else 2500) = foldr1 mat_mult (map A [1..50])"
shows  "\<forall> k. A k * A (k+1) = mat 2 2 (\<lambda>(i, j). if i = j then 1 else if j = 1 then 0 else 2*(k+1)^2)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Consider a sequence of 2x2 matrices $A_k$ where each $A_k$ is defined as follows: for each $i$ and $j$, the $(i,j)$-entry of $A_k$ is 1 if $i$ equals $j$, 0 if $j$ equals 1, and $2k$ otherwise. Now suppose that the matrix obtained by multiplying all the matrices from $A_1$ to $A_{50}$ together is a 2x2 matrix where each $(i,j)$-entry is 1 if $i$ equals $j$, 0 if $j$ equals 1, and 2500 otherwise. Prove that for all $k$, the product of $A_k$ and $A_{k+1}$ is a 2x2 matrix where each $(i,j)$-entry is 1 if $i$ equals $j$, 0 if $j$ equals 1, and $2*(k+1)^2$ otherwise.
